project.announcement:
Producer: Emily Project Manager: Emily Client: Mohammad Ghanoonparvar Grammar Content Provider: Koorosh Angali Instructional Content Providers: Blake Atwood, Shahla Adel FINAL URL: http://www.laits.utexas.edu/persian_grammar/
Persian Online is a site for second language learners of Persian designed to be open to a worldwide audience. It will contain both basic grammar for beginning, intermediate, and advanced students, as well as a glossary, bibliography, and audio and video multimedia content.
Goal for Spring Semester 2007:
Complete a 20-40 page prototype to be tested by beginning and intermediate Persian classes on campus.
Goal for Summer 2007:
Review findings of user testing of prototype, and determine next steps for content development and possible content management.
Updates: New design utilizes 7 wordpress "blogs" to preserve content flexibility. Grammar has been separated into a separate section. A new structure for instructional sections is being developed. Goal is SIX to EIGHT sample lessons, with multimedia, for Fall 2008.
Accomplished: 5 lessons for Fall 2008 in E1. Continue to port over and revise grammar content as tech support is available.
New goal for Dec 2008: All E1 lessons tested in class and finalized: one lesson in E2, I1, and I2 (Moh, Shahla, Blake). and May 2009: Grammar formatting and audio recording, and audio tagging completed (Ran)
Stand alone DVD version delivered May 30. Submitted to search engines by May 30. Project functionally complete.
Emily
project.name: Persian Online

project.announcement:
Producer: Emily Project Manager: Daniel Client: Mohammad Al-Batal ORIGINAL URL: http://www.aswaatarabiyya.emory.edu/ TRANSITIONAL URL: http://www.laits.utexas.edu/arabic_listening RELEASE URL: http://www.laits.utexas.edu/aswaat
Aswaat Arabiyya is an resource for intermediate to advanced students of Arabic, featuring a rich variety of video content collected from native speakers and primary cultural sources. It was originally created at Emory University but Dr. Al-Batal would like to have it hosted here, so that he can continue to develop (edit and add) the existing content. Our challenge is that the application was created in Director, and we don’t currently support this at the server level. Also, the original app requires that the user download a significant amount of files, and while this is not done in such a way that it affects the limited copyright of the content material, it does provide ongoing support issues, and may feel too cumbersome to a modern user. We are exploring the redesign of the site in Flash, but this poses both functionality and server issues. We are working in partnership with Scott Hendrick of DIIA to investigate the Flash option, but no final decision to move forward has been made to date.
Goal for Spring 2007:
Complete a demo Flash player prototype for video delivery and fully investigate pros and cons of redesign of site in Flash, including server/hosting implications.
Revision April 2007:
Prototype player has been delivered, has some issues with sync but is promising.
Meanwhile, Emory is unable to continue hosting past June 07: we are completing a report of the existing director site to UT servers.
Also, planning for a “full force” redesign: new content production concurrent with site redesign: Dedicated station for final cut editing, new visual design, fully functioning player client by perhaps Oct 2007; aim for public launch as early as January 2008. Comments Trash Emily Cicchini said… (15 Aug 07, looking at version 2) Indicator
Update: On target for delivery of flash-based “Aswaat Arabiyya 2.0” by January 2008. Update: 209 videos, double the original content, launched May 2008. Flashpaper support target date: Sept 2008.
project.name: Aswaat Arabiyya

Both have been maintained by a variety of STAs and Middle Eastern Studies student workers, including Dart Risely III, Lindsey Jones, Kelsey Innis (No longer active), and Kathy Chung.
Emily Cicchini is project managing: These are not formal LAITS Faculty grants, but "walk-ins."
project.name: Alkitaab Textbook & Arabic Teaching Resources

project.announcement:
Faculty Developer: Kristen Brustad Project Manager: Emily Cicchini DEV URL: http://dev.laits.utexas.edu/arabic_dialects/
This project aims to create an Arabic Dialects website that will serve both Arabic and Linguistics students, faculty, and visiting researchers at The University of Texas at Austin. It is behind an EID. The website will house a well-indexed, searchable online databank containing over fifty hours of audio and audio-visual materials in different dialects across the Arab world, from Morocco to the Gulf. These materials consist of authentic listening passages in a range of Arabic dialects and registers, most of which were collected by the Project Director in the field, supplemented by contributions from students and colleagues.
Tasks include:
1. Digitizing approx. 50 video tapes and 20 audio cassettes of existing dialect material 2. Cataloging and creating multiple level indexes for flexible searching
Deadline: July 15 07 Who: Gary will work with STA’s to support Brustad.
3. Web design with audio and video players, EID authentication, and robust search function
4. Labeling of content to enable complex searching (possibly DASE)
Deadline: Dec 15 07 Who: Brustad and MES Grad student, LAITS TBD
5. Populate a prototype, possible content managed, possibly MT
Deadline: Feb 1 08 Who: TBD
6. Evaluate and revise, make plan for addition content inclusion
Deadline; May 08 Who: Brusted, TBD
UPDATE: Alex added to project. Kaley moves on. Alex works on identifying countries and cities for all target countries. Brustad continues to develop text content; Alex works on source audio and video digitization and selection. Target for first 4 countries: Fall, 2008. For next 4: Spring, 2008.
project.name: Arabic Dialects

project.announcement:
Faculty Developer: Coleman Hutchison Additional Content Provider: Olin Bjork (off campus) Additional Tech Support: Scott Herrick (DIIA) Key STA: David Choi Key LAITS Staff: Michael Heidenreich Emily Cicchini, Project Manager DEV URL: http://www.laits.utexas.edu/leaves/leaves12v4.html
Flash based interactive audio text for Dept of English instructional purposes.
Goal: to illustrate difference between casual contemporary and nineteenth century readings of the text of “Songs of Myself,” part of Leaves of Grass.
Prototyping in classes: Fall, 2008. Goal for this iteration completion: Spring, 2009.
Audio text build from tech of Paradise Lost, Olin will still work on through Fall semester. Need to find an STA to pick up the work at that time. Coleman wants essentially the same interface. Some images from whitmanarchive.org, he will handle rights clearances.
Prototype is already working, with some tweaking still happening: “fish-eye” function for close ups, possible ditch of relative sizing of windows, perhaps use of flashpaper feature. NOTE: Can/should the flash player handle multiple choice of streams on user’s demand: i.e., can they choose voices?
Will include annotations, comparisons of versions (key passages only), and SIX alternative voiced versions of the text. Text comprized of 52 sections, each section to be recorded in units of natural stanzas of 2 or more lines.
Diversity of voices is key. Will hold “auditions” from wide pool across campus. Six voices ideal, 3 male, 3 female, two relatively standard, others with variations. Has some funds to pay. Might “audio test” before final selection.
Coleman will direct and coach performances in the audio studio.
Also discussed NEH grants: see development notes. Also: possible sections for “how to use this site,” additional activities, recordings of alternative text, etc.
Flash with some CSS/HTML pages for ease of future development may be key.
TIMELINE:
AUG-DEC: Prototype development with code and existing text. Annotation development by faculty. STA assigned and trained by Olin (long distance). JAN-MAY: Talent selection, rehearsal, recording. JUNE-AUGUST: Selection of primary and additional audio and coding.
Updates: On track for Audio in FALL 2008. Will probably need additional time for annotation components.
project.name: Song of Myself - Audiotext Project
Video production system and workflow rebuild

project.announcement:
Faculty Developer: Sam Baker (Back ups: Coleman Hutchison, Lars Hinrichs Grad Student Developer/Programmer: Travis Brown Project coordinator: Kate Beutner Project Manager: Emily Cicchini DEV URL: http://ecomma.cwrl.utexas.edu/0.2.0/ DEMO OF NEW DESIGN 8/30/2008: http://rubricated.com/ecomma/demos/blue.xhtml http://rubricated.com/ecomma/demos/blue.png
e-comma, or the "e-Commentary Machine" is a tool for collaboratively marking up literary texts with comments and tags. Travis Brown is doing all the development with the aid of some help from Will McCutchen and other students provided by DIIA. It's housed on the CWRL servers.
Goal: Testing the in Fall of 2007: completed. Funding from NEH Digital Start Up project secured Spring 2008. Revisions continue in Spring and Summer of 2008. Possible collaborative project with HRC reported in June 2008.
project.name: E-Commentary Machine (eComma)

project.announcement: A multicomponent project that will revise lower-division Spanish instruction by intergrating (1) a database (corpus) of Spanish language uses that can be used as both a research resource and as source material for the following three components; (2) training videos for lower-division Spanish instructors; (3) exercises, lesson plans, and multimedia teaching material for Spanish instructors; (4) a website housing comprehensive course materials for students.
project.name: Spanish Course Materials Project (Salaberry)

project.announcement:
LAITS will create a set of video clips featuring UT-associated experts discussing Constitutional issues and themes related to the electoral process in the United States as part of UT's federal mandate to provide educational material related to the ratification of the Constitution. The 2008 project also includes a redesign of the website that (1) makes the substantive content of the videos more transparent to users; (2) organizes the video according to theme and/or subject rather than the year the video was produced; (3) makes content more flexibly and easily managed for the posting of future video content.
Project manager / video production: Daniel Garza Web design and coding: Ming Gong Written content: Jim Henson Audio production: Mike Heidenreich Producer / Client: Jim Henson
project.name: Constitution Day website

project.announcement:
Faculty Developer: Lars Hinrichs Project Manager: Emily Cicchini Video Consultation: Daniel Garza General Content Consultation: Carl Blyth, Hans Boas, Sam Baker, Norma Mendoza Denton Programming Consultation: Peter Keane and Travis Brown, (John Gallner?) ALSO: FastTex/DIIA support is expected
No LAITS server presence as of yet: Project has 2 terabyte raids dedicated for video storage.
This project involves sociolinguistic research using students and field collected multimedia of Texas English speakers (audio and video). The project will begin by prototyping the collection and editing process of short (10 minute) documentary films to ultimately be presented on the web. It corresponds with a class and research proposed by Professor Lars Hinrichs of the Department of English, and may work collaboratively with e-comma and the Texas German Dialect Projects.
MAIN SHORT RANGE GOAL: Creation of prototype video by April, 2009 delivered online.
project.name: Texas English Project

project.announcement:
Producer: Jim Henson Project Manager: Michael Heidenreich Client: John McKiernan-Gonzalez
Onda Latina is an audio archive of the Mexican American Experience, a radio show produced by the Longhorn Radio Network from the late 1970's through the early 1980's. This archive will create a searchable audio database of 200 hours of Latino community radio broadcasts for undergraduates, as well as specialists in Latino studies, American cultural history and Texas Politics. We are working with Kelly Kerbow from The Benson Library to obtain the original recordings of these broadcasts and with Coco Kishi and Justin Olmanson of DIIA in the creation of the website.
Goals for Fall 2008: Digitize a majority of the 198 radio broadcasts, decide on and begin to enter the best metadata for each recording and begin testing the website design.
Goals for Spring 2009: Finish digitizing radio broadcasts, finish entering metadata for each recording and work on website creation.
Goals for Summer 2009: Finish website.
Goals for Fall 2009: Begin testing of website functions.
Goals for Spring 2010: Begin using website in class.
project.name: The Onda Latina Project: Digitizing the Mexican American Experience in the Longhorn Radio Network
3-D Imaging and Materials for Archaeology and Physical Anthropology

project.announcement:
Developer: Rachel Showstack Faculty Advisors: Dale Koike and Almeida Toribio Project Producer: Jim Henson Project Manager: Emily Cicchini
This scope of this project on behalf of LAITS is to provide funds for a student content developer and support the online delivery of audio files and metadata provided that feature Texas Spanish Speakers. DIIA FastTex is developing a website for this project concurrently.
Project scope:
1) Dale Kokie and Jacqueline Toribio will faculty supervisors for this project, which will be a prototype for possible future use by the Department of Spanish. 2) LAITS will continue to provide funding for student support as per the award letter. 3) LAITS will also provide client support to DIIA for web development using DASe, according to the project work flow chart (see attached). Peter Keane will be the tech lead on this aspect of the project, meaning that he will work directly on the implementation with DIIA FastTex students. 4) LAITS will provide graphic design for a limited amount of PDF instructional materials as a walk-in project via the STA program in lieu of web-based exercises for this stage of the project. Suloni Robertson will be your contact for this aspect. 5) It is our understanding that DIIA will continue to design and develop the website and user interface, but will not be developing an administrative back end separately from DASe (to help better accommodate any potential for future support). It is also our understanding that DIIA will continue to host and support your website indefinitely, unless otherwise requested by the Department of Spanish. LAITS will continue to support the aspects of your site built upon DASe indefinitely, as well. (6) All work for this grant to be completed by August 31, 2010
Revised 11/18/2009 EC
project.name: Texas Spanish Project - Showstack/Koike/Toribio

project.announcement:
Faculty Lead: Naoko Suito Project Manager: Emily Cicchini Tech Lead: Ran An Project Producer: Jim Henson Additional Support: James Lewis, Networks, and Peter Keane, Programming
Project Scope: This project has several components.
1) A series of videos produced by DIIA over last summer and a database for delivering these videos need to be incorporated into the website.
2) A set of existing quizes need to be upgraded to meet standard security requirements.
3) A set of new quizes need to be made that meet standard security requirements.
Our goal is to have new quizes available for classes by the Spring of 2009, and the existing quizes retrofitted as soon as possible. The video database is being revised to be managed through DASe.
We are still investigating the best way to deliver quizes with student identifiable grade-level data.
REV - 11/18/2009 EC
project.name: JOSHU / Katakana Projects

project.announcement:
Content Contributors: Penne L Restad Rebecca
Project Manager: Suloni Robertson
Word Press Support: Anne Alexander
Site Design: LAITS Student Technology Assistants and professional developers on staff
Description: The American History survey course site needs to serve several purposes: Students will use it as a content base for the course. It will also serve to create an image of the course as unique from the other American history courses, and not incidentally to help make students more comfortable with approaching history in a somewhat non-traditional way. Because this course is being created as a result of a System grant for Transforming Undergraduate Education, the site should also provide colleagues an idea of what we are attempting in the course.
project.name: American History survey course: WordPress project

project.announcement: Responsibility the technical needs of walk-in projects rests finally with professional staff even when STAs carry through most or all of the work. This site tracks assignments of professional staff to each walk-in project. It also provides a forum for communication among the STA supervisor, the project manager if any, and professional staff responsible for each walk-in project.
project.name: Walk-In Project Staff Tech Leads

project.announcement:
This is a strategic project to support the Department of Asian Studies and Hindi-Urdu Flagship program. It involves video instruction of Hindi Medical Terminology, with original video footage shot by a third party company in India, who will be providing finished video, translations, and transcriptions. DIIA FastTex is proving post production of this video, and may be creating a custom video player that is capable of searching video by vocabulary word. (this is a wish list item not a criteria). Faculty Developer Jishnu will be overseeing the selection and identification of vocabulary and definitions, and advanced listening comprehension self-test exercises will be multiple choice & short answer and delivered on the web without user log in. It will be open access. The deadline for a live release under the external grant calendar is December, 2010, with a target of 20 completed video/vocabulary prototype units. Must be able to be continually updated, additional video and content to be developed indefinately.
The contact is Jishnu Shankar jshankar@austin.utexas.edu
There is a DASe collection started for this site. Suloni is signed on to do a design: The Medical Terminology will probably be done in wordpress or drupal, the scope for the instructional site is still indetermined.
project.name: Hindi Medical Terminology
